mods.abstract: 27a: Female adult, Navajo woman, medium brown cloth head and all body, painted features, black hair wig, white yarn tied at the back of the hair, red velvet blouse with bead buttons, leather belt with metallic decorated beads, bead decoration on sleeves, blue stain skirt with red ric-rac decoration, bead earrings and necklace, she is sitting on wooden board and weaving navajo blanket, baby doll is on cradle beside her, four colors of yarn balls are on other side, machine-made. Accompanying information describes as blue of the sky, red of the desert color Navajo life. The industrious Navajo, largest and one of the most adaptable of the united States tribes today weave bright blankets, rugs and work silver and turquoise with traditional artistry. The style of dress dates back to early Spanish invasions.""
mods.accessCondition: Please submit an LSU Special Collections reference ticket at https://askus.lib.lsu.edu/special for any questions or comments about this digital object.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Transformed into MODS from extended Dublin Core by the LDL Development Team at Louisiana State University.
